page.title: 11DERWENT VALLEY - WILD LIFE
page.content: Despite increasing human pressure, the area abounds in wildlife. Of the larger animals the roe deer, badger and fox are well represented in spite of a long history of persecution. The red squirrel abound whilst the otter, once thought to have disappeared, has been seen recently since the closure of a mink farm near High Spen. Anglers use the River Derwent which is stocked from a trout farm at Lintzford. Many varieties of birds, both resident and migrant, are in the area. The drive, spearheaded by the Angling Club, to reduce pollution, has resulted in the increase of kingfisher numbers. Other water birds include heron, dipper, water-hen, mallard, sedge-warbler and pied and grey wagtail. The most common bird of prey is the tawny owl, but kestrel and sparrow-hawk are also found.
